hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input data. You have a list of tasks, each with an ID, an assignee, and a submission date. Focus on how to extract the submission dates from this structure.
Next, consider how to identify which dates fall on the weekend. In most programming languages, you can use date libraries to determine the day of the week for a given date.
Remember that weekends typically consist of Saturday and Sunday. Make sure your logic accounts for both days when checking if a date is a weekend.
To process the dates, you might want to convert the submission date strings into date objects. This will allow you to easily manipulate and check the day of the week.
Think about how you will count the tasks submitted on weekends. You could use a counter variable that increments every time you find a weekend date.
Consider edge cases, such as what happens if there are no tasks submitted on weekends. Your function should handle this gracefully and return a count of zero in such cases.
As you implement your solution, remember to iterate through the list of tasks. For each task, check if the submission date falls on a weekend and update your count accordingly.
You may want to use a helper function to determine if a specific date is a weekend. This function can take a date object and return true or false based on the day of the week.
When you're ready to finalize your solution, ensure that your function returns the total count of tasks submitted on weekends. This should be a single integer value.
Before you finish, test your solution with various inputs, including edge cases like all tasks on weekdays, all on weekends, and mixed cases to ensure accuracy.

questionNotes: Input consists of a list of tasks with task_id, assignee_id, and submit_date.
Weekend days are Saturday and Sunday.
Return a single integer count of tasks submitted on weekends.
Handle cases with no weekend tasks by returning 0.
